info.game_comments: Battle of the Decades: The 1990s game 4.

(1, 1).clue: Home to a chuckwalla lizard breeding program, Henry Doorly Zoo is found in this city

(3, 1).clue: Ring my bell! Pavlov did to produce this fluid in dogs

(4, 1).clue: This Hemingway novel takes place over 3 days near Segovia, Spain in 1937

(5, 1).clue: It was before I had a cell phone, so when I said, "hit me on the hip" I meant contact me via this device

(6, 1).clue: This French preposition means "at the home of"

(1, 2).clue: The Loup & the Elkhorn are the 2 major tributaries of this river that in turn flows into the Missouri

(2, 2).clue: The Everly Brothers sang, "I die each time I hear this sound":"____'s Clown"

(3, 2).clue: Pleural fluid is found in a sac in this cavity; an excess buildup of it is not good

(4, 2).clue: In a kids' book, Chester is this title type of insect who comes from Connecticut to live in Times Square

(5, 2).clue: The "pump" from this company was a shoe you pumped up with air for a snugger fit

(6, 2).clue: Here's our theme in this musical style associated with Vienna

(1, 3).clue: An 1875 visitor called Ogallala "Gomorrah of the cattle trail...(3/4) dance halls, gambling houses &" these to drink in

(3, 3).clue: No joke, a gel called the vitreous this fills the space between the retina & the lens of your eye

(4, 3).clue: "The Devil's Candy" chronicled the disastrous film production of this Tom Wolfe bestseller

(5, 3).clue: Suzanne Somers squeezed out a small fortune advertising this exercise product in the 1990s; I've still got mine

(6, 3).clue: A court officer cries this twice to get silence before a session

(1, 4).clue: Pawnee City is home to one of the largest collections of this kind of fencing material

(2, 4).clue: Fountains of Wayne had the hots for her:"____'s Mom"

(3, 4).clue: Plasma is blood without cells; this is blood without cells & clotting factors

(4, 4).clue: This Italian literary critic wrote the 1988 novel "Foucault's Pendulum"

(5, 4).clue: This global phenomenon featuring a guy in a red & white striped shirt & cap sold 47 million books worldwide

(6, 4).clue: The chow chow & Samoyed are this type of dog with thick fur & a tail curled over the back

(1, 5).clue: This monument near Alliance is a display of half-buried vehicles that looks like an older British landmark

(3, 5).clue: The liver sends this alkaline liquid to the gallbladder to help with digestion

(4, 5).clue: In the "Nun's Priest's Tale", Chaucer used some of the French material about this fox of medieval French fable

(5, 5).clue: Infomercialshelped popularize this martial arts-basedworkout with a Korean-derived name

(6, 5).clue: Ax-like tool with a chisel-like steel head

(1, 1).clue: In a Jack London story, a jute mill worker breathes air "thick with" this substance that fills his lungs (& belly button)

(2, 1).clue: A young physician makes a new life for herself in the Old West

(3, 1).clue: "M" is for this man who died just 5 years after his son passed away at age 777

(4, 1).clue: In 1982 this future German chancellor got a divorce after 5 years of marriage but kept the last name

(5, 1).clue: This seat, the title of a Thurber story, is a position of great advantage

(6, 1).clue: In North America:Goat Island & Navy Island

(1, 2).clue: Jute served the British Empire as a billion sandbags lined these World War I pits that gave their name to a type of warfare

(2, 2).clue: A young woman's murder in a small Pacific northwest town leads to a mystery

(3, 2).clue: "P" es for these people whom Jesus calls "hypocrites" & "ye generation of vipers"

(4, 2).clue: Divorce & remarriage to a divorcee named Happy helped kill a 1964 presidential bid by this rich GOP moderate

(5, 2).clue: It's the point in the orbit of a planet at which it's nearest to the sun

(6, 2).clue: In the Midwest:Blanchard Island & Kaskaskia island (until the silt came)

(1, 3).clue: A big 19th century discovery: jute makes good carpet backing if mixed with this politically incorrect oil

(2, 3).clue: A free-spirited yoga instructor marries a conservative attorney on their first date

(3, 3).clue: "J" is for this man, who says, "my brother is a hairy man, and I am a smooth man"

(4, 3).clue: Their storybook royal romance produced 2 daughters but ended in 1996

(5, 3).clue: This French phrase refers to a form of psychosis in which 2 people share the same delusions

(1, 4).clue: Jute is made into this material with a weapon in its name, often followed by "sack"

(2, 4).clue: Staffers must stop the dimwitted mayor of NYC from making a fool of himself

(3, 4).clue: "E" is for this city in "witch" king Saul gets very bad news

(4, 4).clue: Andrew Jackson loved her so much he married her twice; her divorce from an army officer wasn't final the first time

(5, 4).clue: This 3-letfer Hindi word is used in India as a title of respect for a man

(6, 4).clue: Off continental Europe:Temple Mill Island & Eel Pie Island

(1, 5).clue: Around 1900 the center of jute production moved from Dundee, Scotland to this present capital of West Bengal, India

(2, 5).clue: A self-absorbed TV personality urges his audience, "No flipping!"

(3, 5).clue: "C" is for this high priest who presided over Jesus' first trial

(4, 5).clue: Around 1880 this Irish nationalist leader said, hello, Kitty O'Shea, leading to her divorce & his political ruin

(5, 5).clue: Often seen in crosswords, this 4-letter word for a small decorative case to hold needles is from the Old French

(0, 0).clue: He's the most recent winner of 2 Pulitzer prizes for fiction, winning in 1982 & 1991 for books in the same series
